translation.en: It's very difficult to stand up to a company
as big and as influential as Google.
It was discussed within Art+Com, of course,
how to deal with Google
and with what they were doing with Google Earth, in particular.
translation.ko: 그리고 특히 구글 어스 문제를 어떻게 다룰지요

translation.en: And I was also there when they started the lawsuit.
translation.ko: 전 소송이 시작됐을 때도 거기 있었어요

translation.en: American trials are like a big show.
And I doubt that helps with uncovering truth.
The first thing I saw was a side-by-side video
translation.ko: 제가 처음 본 건 1990년대 중반에 만든

translation.en: of Terravision in the mid-'90s.
I think flying into Kyoto.
On the right half of the screen was video of the same route taken by Google Earth.
translation.ko: 화면의 오른쪽엔 구글 어스로 본 같은 경로 영상이었어요

translation.en: And it was absolutely identical.
Of course, we hoped that at least the truth would come out
and that the world would find out who really invented Google Earth.
translation.ko: 누가 구글 어스를 발명했는지 세상 사람들이 알게 되는 거였어요

translation.en: It started as a mess and turned into a much bigger mess
translation.ko: 엉망진창으로 시작됐는데 더 큰 엉망진창이 됐고

translation.en: and an expensive mess.
From the military-industrial complex this looked really nice.
I do believe that's the reason why the CIA eventually put money into this.
translation.ko: 그래서 결국 CIA가 이 기술에 투자한 거라고 생각해요

translation.en: In the beginning, only a couple million was at stake
and later it was like 3/4 of a billion.
Things escalated quickly.
I couldn't believe that this is really a true story based on true events.
translation.ko: 이게 실제 사건에 기반한 실화라는 게 믿기지 않아요

translation.en: Did I know that? No, I didn't.
I didn't know about Terravision or Art+Com.
translation.ko: 테라비전이나 아트+컴에 대해 몰랐어요 "요하나 폴라이 배우"

translation.en: I mean, if you google it, there are not many results
who show you the trial and the whole thing, like the…
the thing that happened.
Because you google it!
Rock and roll, it was dead.
I arrived shortly after the wall came down.
translation.ko: 전 베를린 장벽이 무너진 직후에 도착했어요 "파펠 마이어 리얼리티 엔지니어, 테라비전"

translation.en: For me, it was really refreshing compared to West Germany.
Something new appeared and something old disappeared.
translation.ko: 새로운 게 나타났고 오래된 게 사라졌죠

translation.en: So a lot of opportunities.
It was a time of unlimited possibilities. You could try and do anything.
translation.ko: 무한의 가능성이 있던 시절이었고 무엇이든 할 수 있었어요 "악셀 슈미트 아이디어 & 3D 렌더러"

translation.en: There was this period of optimism and of chance.
Everything is possible.
An empty house was turned into a cafe.
An old bunker was turned into a club.
So for a short period of time, there was a lot of free space and freedom.
translation.ko: "요아힘 자우터 콘셉트 & 아트 디렉션" 짧은 기간 동안 자유 공간과 자유가 많았어요

translation.en: It was a nice form of anarchy.
Wild clubs.
In the center of the city, you had some places where there was a hole in the wall.
translation.ko: 도시 한복판에 벽에 구멍이 난 곳들이 있었고 "게르트 그루나이스 프로젝트 매니저"

translation.en: And you could go down in the cellar.
Dark and noisy.
And sweaty.
And minimal in a way.
translation.ko: 어떤 면에선 단순했어요 "주자네 야슈코 아트 큐레이터"

translation.en: And techno.
There was a famous club, Kunst und Technik.
I think it was illegal.
Very interesting space where the artist could experiment
translation.ko: 예술가가 실험할 수 있는 흥미로운 곳이었고

translation.en: and you could suddenly interact with some graphic on the floor.
translation.ko: 바닥에 있는 그래픽으로 갑자기 소통할 수 있었죠

translation.en: These were parallel worlds in a way.
Yeah. People didn't wanna have anything to do with computers.
As did the whole art scene.
They were also like, "Computers were bad things."
They were like tools of oppression and control.
But there was a minority who wanted it and so they founded Art+Com.
translation.ko: 하지만 그걸 원했던 소수가 있었고 그들이 아트+컴을 설립했어요

translation.en: Art+Com was an open space for experimentation.
People with different skills and backgrounds thrown together
translation.ko: 각기 다른 기술과 배경을 가진 사람들이

translation.en: with the goal of creating something new.
Computers were an unknown medium
and we wanted to discover the possibilities of the digital world.
translation.ko: 우린 디지털 세계의 가능성을 알아내고 싶었어요

translation.en: Money was not the motivation.
We wanted to be pioneers.
The idea behind Art+Com was
interdisciplinary work,
to bring architects, artists, computer scientists together.
Art+Com's work extends beyond a regular multimedia business.
translation.ko: 아트+컴의 업무는 일반적인 멀티미디어 사업을 초월합니다

translation.en: With the help of supercomputers, we enter cyberspace.
translation.ko: 슈퍼컴퓨터의 도움을 받아 사이버 공간으로 들어갑니다

translation.en: They generate an artificial reality with a keyboard and mouse.
At the time when we started,
computers were really expensive.
They were locked in the vaults of banks.
Still, we managed to get our hands on the latest machines
translation.ko: 하지만 우린 최신 컴퓨터를 확보할 수 있었고

translation.en: to try what was technically possible.
It was an adult playground.
They could buy these refrigerator-sized 3D engines
and do whatever they pleased with it.
That was the new RealityEngine,
a graphics engine from Silicon Graphics.
The biggest and best back then.
We unwrapped it, took a look, and it just sat there.
translation.ko: 포장을 뜯고 훑어본 후에 그냥 뒀는데

translation.en: And eventually someone said, "Oh, you don't have a PC, use that one."
These Silicon Graphics machines, they cost hundred thousands of dollars.
All of a sudden, I, as a student, had the biggest computer in the company.
translation.ko: 갑자기 학생인 제가 가장 큰 PC를 갖게 됐죠

translation.en: And I just started messing around.
I compiled the demos and wrote programs.
I tried to figure out how to best utilize the graphics card.
At some point, I had a spinning globe on screen.
I noticed that it was not that great. When you zoomed in, it got blurry.
translation.ko: 제가 보기엔 별로 대단하지 않았고 확대하면 흐려졌죠

translation.en: I messed around a bit.
There was an option that was not well-documented back then.
translation.ko: 그 당시 기록되지 않은 옵션이 있었는데

translation.en: By chance, I figured out
how to zoom in.
Then, I don't know, we were standing around looking at it,
translation.ko: 다들 모여서 그걸 봤고 사람들은 아이디어를 냈어요

translation.en: and everyone was having ideas, and that's how it slowly evolved.
translation.ko: 다들 모여서 그걸 봤고 사람들은 아이디어를 냈어요 그렇게 천천히 진화했죠

translation.en: It was the first attempt to connect the loose ends of the world
translation.ko: 디지털 공간이란 수단을 통해 전 세계 곳곳을

translation.en: through the means of digital space.
How can you connect yourself with, let's say, Tokyo in an instant?
translation.ko: 어떻게 나와 도쿄를 즉시 연결할 수 있을까요?

translation.en: We wanted to create a space for people to see
and understand the world without being there.
translation.ko: 이해할 수 있는 공간을 만들고 싶었습니다

translation.en: We also wanted to understand what interactivity and engagement did
translation.ko: 또한 쌍방향성과 관여가 정보에 어떤 영향을 미치는지

translation.en: to the meaning of information.
That was basically the beginning of Terravision.
The core team was Pavel, Joachim, Axel and me.
translation.ko: 핵심 팀은 파펠, 요아힘 악셀과 저였어요

translation.en: And it was like Pavel and Axel, the programmers,
where Axel mainly programmed the renderer itself.
Pavel was for everything around,
the backend and the data connections and everything.
Joachim did some conceptual art for the interfaces.
I was responsible for all the data integration.
No, no. I'm no coder.
I'm really a computer artist. This I had always been.
There was a science fiction by Neal Stephenson.
It was called Snow Crash.
The idea of virtual representation of the real world.
translation.ko: 현실 세계를 가상 공간에서 보여준 작품이었어요

translation.en: Terravision was then the system
where we wanted to put everything in that we wanted to visualize.
translation.ko: 시각화하고 싶은 걸 전부 넣을 수 있는 시스템이었죠

translation.en: We started with a very rough Earth.
Later on, we could overlay all kinds of additional information
translation.ko: 나중에 날씨 데이터 같은 추가 데이터의

translation.en: like weather data, designing a complete virtual world.
translation.ko: 오버레이를 통해 완전한 가상 세계를 설계했죠

translation.en: We had no real limit on the size of our model.
We could go through in real time.
Art+Com basically initiated a process with Terravision.
They built the technical and the conceptual foundation.
In the end, it's the users of the system who complete the system.
We submitted an application to Telekom
in order to get funding.
They were into it right away, saying, "Yes, let's do that."
We got funding because of, yeah, the Cold War basically.
translation.ko: 기본적으로 냉전 덕분에 자금을 확보한 거죠

translation.en: And because the Federal Republic was funneling hundreds of millions into Berlin
translation.ko: 연방 공화국이 베를린으로 수백만 달러를 쏟아부었는데

translation.en: and somehow we got attached to that money stream
and were able to do really cool things.
We were a team of four.
And we basically kept developing it,
until at some point, Telekom,
who of course wanted to know what we were doing with the money,
translation.ko: 우리가 뭘 하는지 보고 싶어 했고

translation.en: told us in 1995
to present our project at the ITU conference in Kyoto.
This exhibition featured the opening of the data highway
translation.ko: 이 전시회는 독일과 일본 간 데이터 하이웨이를

translation.en: between Germany and Japan.
T-Vision was a part of the virtual ribbon-cutting ceremony
translation.ko: 티비전은 새로운 인포반을 위한 가상 개관식의

translation.en: for this new infobahn.
Before the Kyoto conference, it was a very stressful time in Berlin.
translation.ko: 교토에 가기 전 베를린에서 스트레스가 극심했어요

translation.en: Because nothing worked.
There were bits here and there we could demonstrate
but the system wasn't presentable.
Nothing was working.
This was the first time we showed Terravision
and we had to work every day and night to get it running.
I think that was the most stressful time in my life.
translation.ko: 그때가 제 평생 가장 스트레스가 심했던 때였죠

translation.en: If we wouldn't be successful with Terravision in Kyoto,
it would have been the end of Art+Com.
So everyone would have lost their jobs
and it would have been the end of the story,
so that was the kind of pressure.
Pavel and I sat next to each other in a big room.
translation.ko: 파펠과 전 큰 방에 나란히 앉아 있었어요

translation.en: I remember, at some point I heard a thud.
translation.ko: 어느 순간 쿵 하는 소리가 났고

translation.en: I turned around and Pavel had fallen off his chair.
I was so busy with coding
that I didn't even help him up.
I don't know myself how that could happen.
So I told Henrik,
"Hey Pavel's on the floor, can you check?"
And Henrik drove to the hospital with Pavel.
He needed to be in an oxygen tent. He basically needed to be revived.
translation.ko: 파펠은 산소 텐트가 필요했고 기력을 회복해야 했죠

translation.en: An hour later, he came back and started working again.
translation.ko: 한 시간 뒤 파펠은 돌아왔고 계속 일했어요

translation.en: The Telekom people, they got really nervous.
They thought this would be a complete disaster!
The night before the conference,
we worked the entire night. The conference began at 9 a.m.
translation.ko: 밤샘 작업을 했어요 콘퍼런스는 아침 9시에 시작됐죠

translation.en: And then shortly before the conference opened,
we restarted the system
and thought, "Well, it might work now."
No one wanted to talk to us.
Everyone turned away and called back home and said,
"Well, that's the end of Art+Com. We can't work with them anymore."
translation.ko: '이제 아트+컴은 끝장이야 더는 그들과 일할 수 없어'

translation.en: I remember, at some point the globe
showed up on screen.
And it actually worked.
Very carefully we moved the earth tracker, our interface
translation.ko: 지구본을 돌리기 위해 조심스럽게 우리 인터페이스인

translation.en: in order to turn the globe.
And it moved, and the space mouse worked too.
translation.ko: 움직였어요 스페이스 마우스도요 그랬더니 날기 시작했죠

translation.en: You could really start flying around.
That was sensational.
There was some big competition there. AT&T had a huge screen
translation.ko: 거기엔 큰 경쟁사가 있었어요 AT&T는 대형 화면으로

translation.en: with colorful pics.
They presented great things. But everyone wanted to see Terravision.
translation.ko: 그들은 대단한 걸 보여줬지만 모두 테라비전을 보길 원했고

translation.en: Crowds of people were gathered around our small screen.
translation.ko: 우리의 작은 화면 주위에 많은 사람이 모여들었죠

translation.en: No one cared for the other presentations.
Everyone was our friend.
All of a sudden, we were invited everywhere.
They were all lined up. We were the heroes of Kyoto.
translation.ko: 다들 줄을 섰죠 우린 교토의 영웅이었어요

translation.en: As far as I know, I would not think that anyone did this before.
translation.ko: 제가 아는 한 아무도 그런 걸 한 적이 없었어요

translation.en: Because in this time...
computers were really slow.
So we had to really do some magic
to get this working at all.
We went to the Telekom stock launch
and presented our project
at the New York Stock Exchange on Wall Street.
...with a huge plexiglass ball
and with a huge projection.
We went to the G7 meeting in Brussels.
translation.ko: 우린 브뤼셀에서 열린 G7 회의에도 참석해

translation.en: We presented it to Al Gore.
Everywhere.
Los Angeles, San Francisco.
Traveled the world with it, like a small circus, I would say.
And no one of us could do it by himself.
translation.ko: 그리고 우리 중 아무도 혼자 할 수 없었죠

translation.en: So, we knew that we…just as a group,
we could get this thing done.
And this was really special.
Astronauts always describe this moment,
the view of the world from outer space.
To be able to do that, you know, virtually,
translation.ko: 그걸 가상 공간에서 할 수 있다는 건

translation.en: I think that was a fantastic idea.
Art+Com is Germany's leading research institute for VR.
translation.ko: 아트+컴은 가상 현실 분야에서 독일의 선도적 연구소입니다

translation.en: These software artists from Berlin won a bunch of awards
translation.ko: 베를린의 소프트웨어 아티스트들은 그들의 가상 세계로

translation.en: for their virtual worlds.
We never thought that this would be really such a worldwide thing.
translation.ko: 그게 세계적인 것이 될 줄은 생각도 못 했어요

translation.en: We had big expectations in the beginning. We thought it was gonna be huge.
translation.ko: 초기엔 기대가 컸어요 엄청날 거라고 생각했죠

translation.en: Yeah, it was the dot-com bubble
and typically you raised like tens of millions of dollars
or sometimes hundreds of millions
just based on a single presentation and business plan.
So, that was really crazy.
We noticed that a lot of successful companies were popping up
translation.ko: 우리 주변에 성공적인 회사들이 많이 생겨나기 시작했죠

translation.en: in this emerging Internet. And there were these ideas regarding
translation.ko: 특히 인터넷이 등장했을 때요 우린 모든 걸 통합할

translation.en: integrating all these shops as well. We had all these ideas back then.
But we couldn't realize them yet.
We were a bit too early. Unfortunately.
I would never call Art+Com a startup, you know.
It's coming from such a different culture.
It has nothing to do with a startup.
That wasn't really our thing. We weren't commercially oriented.
translation.ko: 우린 스타트업이 아니었어요 상업적 가치를 지향하지 않았어요

translation.en: We just wanted to do it.
We wanted to see it working
and we didn't think about money. Really not.
translation.ko: 돈 벌 생각은 안 했어요 정말이에요

translation.en: Over the years,
we realized
that it's very difficult
to make it commercially successful.
When you want to sell software to people
who need a half-million-dollar machine to run it,
the market's not that big.
We actually never made money with Terravision.
But no matter what you do, how much fun it is, how great it is,
translation.ko: 하지만 무엇을 하든 얼마나 재미있고 대단하든

translation.en: at some point, it starts to get repetitive and you wanna move on.
translation.ko: 어느 시점엔 반복적인 일이 되고 다른 일을 하고 싶어지죠

translation.en: The digital world is a really fast-going world.
It's like five minutes fame and then it's gone.
Financially, Art+Com wasn't stable anymore.
We realized that. It wasn't enough anymore.
translation.ko: 그걸 깨달았죠 더 이상 충분하지 않았어요

translation.en: Telekom didn't support us anymore.
And yeah, that was basically the end of the project.
I pride myself on knowing a lot of software products
and having used them. I'd never heard of Terravision.
I was really amazed
that this trailblazing software had existed and I didn't know about it.
translation.ko: 그런 선구적인 소프트웨어가 존재했는데 몰랐다는 게요

translation.en: I think that's the sort of background that you have to understand
how much of a leap Terravision was.
There wasn't an Internet. People really hadn't--
Like a PC wasn't something you had at your house.
You may have had one at work. And they came up with this thing
translation.ko: 직장에 하나쯤 있었겠죠 그런데 전 세계를

translation.en: that would let you travel around the world.
One of the guys said, "Okay.
Your problem is you're always five to 35 years ahead of the market."
So we had to wait about a decade.
It's very unfortunate because, really, what did happen in Berlin
was that this was the epicenter of the sort of geo-information system
that we use today on our phones and our computers.
Google launched Google Earth in 2004.
And I saw it and obviously we thought right away,
"That's Terravision."
On the one side, we thought, "Wow, they really did it, no?
They got it working on the Internet."
On the other side, we knew...
who… and how it was done.
And we felt a little betrayed.
I think the copying-- Sorry, I may have to--
The alleged copying had been a lot earlier.
It was not direct from end point of Terravision to Google Earth.
translation.ko: 테라비전에서 구글 어스로 바로 연결된 게 아니에요

translation.en: Between there was one guy who was working for Silicon Graphics.
translation.ko: 그 사이에 실리콘 그래픽스에서 일했던 한 남자가 있었죠

translation.en: I knew right away who was responsible.
It was a certain **** ****
who we met early on in 1995
in Mountain View at Silicon Graphics.
I actually showed him Terravision then.
He said, "Wow, that's a great project.
That's exactly what my bosses want me to do.
translation.ko: '제 상사가 늘 저한테 하라고 했던 건데'

translation.en: And I've always told them it won't work."
He had thought this would be a great demo for his company
translation.ko: 그는 자기 회사에 보여주면 좋을 거라고 생각했어요

translation.en: that he had founded after leaving Silicon Graphics.
translation.ko: 그가 실리콘 그래픽스를 떠난 후에 설립한 회사죠

translation.en: And then that didn't go so well, I heard.
And someone said, "But this demo you have here zooming into the planet,
that's really good."
And so this then became Keyhole, the Keyhole Earth Viewer.
translation.ko: 그리고 그게 키홀이 됐죠 키홀 어스 뷰어

translation.en: Keyhole, to my understanding,
was financed then by the venture capital firm of the CIA.
For anyone concerned with battlefields, this was a big deal.
The equivalent of the card table
on which they would put maps and little wooden soldiers
in the Second World War, they wanted the digital equivalent of it.
It's hard to get the genie back in the bottle.
translation.ko: 지니를 다시 병 속에 집어넣긴 힘들어요

translation.en: In-Q-Tel is a CIA venture capital company.
They knew the potential of what was there for their own needs
translation.ko: 그들은 향후 자기들 일에 필요할 거란 걸 알았고

translation.en: and they wanted to have a kind of grip on this kind of technology.
Maybe this shouldn't be in the documentary.
One of the things I had to do for the law firm
translation.ko: 제가 로펌을 위해 했던 일 중 하나는

translation.en: was to scan every little bit of evidence here.
So I've seen everything.
And there was a lot of military business cards that they had brought back,
translation.ko: 그들이 가져온 군수 업체 명함이 많았는데

translation.en: and the ITU Conference in Kyoto wasn't even a military event.
translation.ko: 교토 ITU 콘퍼런스는 군 행사가 아니었어요

translation.en: We received requests from the military,
but we turned them down flat, of course. That was out of the question for Art+Com.
They built a special system for the CIA
translation.ko: 그들은 CIA를 위해 특별한 시스템을 구축했는데

translation.en: where they could put all their data from the spy satellites in
translation.ko: 스파이 위성에서 얻은 모든 데이터를 입력해서

translation.en: and also combine it into a complete model.
translation.ko: 완전한 모델로 결합할 수 있는 시스템이었죠

translation.en: From the military-industrial complex, this looked really nice.
I do believe that that's the reason
why the CIA eventually put money into this.
When we saw that Google acquired it,
translation.ko: 구글이 그걸 샀다는 걸 알았을 때

translation.en: we had a deeper look at the system.
translation.ko: 그 시스템을 좀 더 심층적으로 검토했죠

translation.en: When it became Google Earth, suddenly it became visible.
translation.ko: 그게 구글 어스가 됐을 때 갑자기 보이더군요

translation.en: I was very deeply looking into how Google Earth worked
translation.ko: 전 구글 어스와 테라비전의 작동 방식을

translation.en: and how Terravision worked.
And the similarities were absolutely striking.
For instance, the way quadrants were addressed
through a string of digits between zero and three--
exactly the same.
So I used a protocol analyzer to look at the request
that Google Earth would send to the server through HTTP,
translation.ko: HTTP를 통해 서버로 보내는 요청을 살펴봤더니

translation.en: and it was exactly what Terravision had done.
So that was my second impression.
It was like, "Someone really copied something here."
Yeah, well, we knew that we had this patent
which made us approach Google.
They were kind of friendly
but it was obvious that they were like handing us down
translation.ko: 자기들이 더 대단하다고 우릴 깔보는 게

translation.en: in their hierarchy.
What they wanted to offer as a compensation was really...
It was not enough.
"Okay, well, we would pay you like $200,000 for the patent."
It was just a joke.
I mean, we spent almost as much on lawyers.
For us to sue Google made no sense.
We were too small and weak. We wouldn't be able to pull that off.
translation.ko: 우린 작고 약해서 성공하지 못할 테니까요

translation.en: So, we put that aside.
Then, we found a law firm in the States with the help of Martin Silbernagel
who was willing to take on the risk.
translation.ko: 미국에 있는 로펌을 알게 됐고 우리 사건을 맡겠다고 했죠

translation.en: It's really incredibly expensive to sue someone in the United States
translation.ko: 미국에 있는 누군가를 특허 침해로 고소하는 건

translation.en: on patent infringement.
In the US, a patent litigation will cost you on the order of $5 million.
translation.ko: 미국에서 특허 소송은 대략 5백만 달러가 들죠

translation.en: This money even larger companies don't have.
So you would normally go to a litigation finance firm
which works a little bit like a venture capital firm.
They look at your case and if they think it's gonna make them back enough money,
translation.ko: 사건을 검토해서 승소할 가능성이 충분하다고 판단하면

translation.en: they'll bankroll you.
So if you don't have a case that has, say, 100 million in damages,
translation.ko: 그래서 1억 달러 정도의 배상금을 받을 사건이 아니면

translation.en: you're not financeable.
It could have cost Google up to a billion dollars of damages.
translation.ko: 구글은 최대 10억 달러의 배상금을 지불했을 수도 있어요

translation.en: What are they gonna do, sue me?
The morning before we filed the complaint, I remember, in my hotel room,
translation.ko: 소송을 제기하기 전날 아침 전 호텔 방에 있었고

translation.en: I moved my private emails off of Gmail onto another server.
translation.ko: 지메일 계정에 있던 제 개인 이메일을 다른 서버로 옮겼어요

translation.en: Google plays dirty.
They do things like have a contract with every appeal law firm
translation.ko: 모든 대형 항소 로펌과 계약을 맺는

translation.en: that's worthwhile.
And so it's very difficult to find a firm that's not conflicted.
translation.ko: 그래서 우리 사건을 맡을 로펌을 찾기가 힘들었죠

translation.en: A lot of people you would talk to will say, "No, I'm sorry.
They are already our client. I can't take you on."
translation.ko: '구글은 저희 고객이라 사건을 맡을 수 없습니다'

translation.en: I think they invested $6 million
and put in a gigantic amount of effort.
Eventually, that led to a trial
where Pavel and I
were cross-examined by Google's lawyers.
And we had to justify ourselves.
Google didn't take us very seriously in the beginning.
translation.ko: 처음에 구글은 우리를 대수롭지 않게 여겼어요

translation.en: It was a bit weird at first but later they--
When it became dangerous, they changed law firms
and did a bunch of other things.
It was like straight out of a movie
and I've never seen an American courtroom from the inside.
translation.ko: 전 미국 법정 내부를 본 적이 없었죠

translation.en: That was, really, a very special experience.
In the end, a jury of laymen decides.
Those are people who don't know anything about it.
And of course they're pro America.
That makes sense.
You could see how this is a company that has just a very good network
translation.ko: 구글이란 회사가 인맥과 재력이 막강하다는 걸

translation.en: and a bunch of money.
I didn't think really justice was served
at that point.
Shortly before, the judge who had worked with us for several years was replaced.
translation.ko: 직전에 우리 사건을 몇 년째 다뤘던 판사가 교체됐어요

translation.en: It was very strange.
Blog entries disappeared in the middle of this court case.
translation.ko: 소송이 진행되는 도중에 블로그 글들이 사라졌죠

translation.en: At some point, people said things like, "Well, I can't find anything
translation.ko: 어느 시점에 사람들이 말했어요 '인터넷에 테라비전 정보가'

translation.en: about Terravision on the Internet."
And, of course, "What are you using to search?"
"Oh, Google." Oh, well, you know.
Yeah. No, they're as evil as anyone else.
Where should the good come from?
I mean, it's a corporation
and it has organs
and it needs to stick to the law
but otherwise it wants to make profit and stay in business.
translation.ko: 최고의 목표는 수익을 내고 사업을 유지하는 거죠

translation.en: We tried to learn throughout the project.
Where does this innovation come from?
translation.ko: 혁신은 어디서 시작되죠? "로베르트 탈하인 '빌리언 달러 코드' 감독"

translation.en: Or what are the factors that bring it together?
translation.ko: "로베르트 탈하인 '빌리언 달러 코드' 감독" 아니면 그걸 가능하게 하는 요인들은 뭘까요?

translation.en: Good question.
If it's self-driven, then I think it's good.
Like the people should burn for it,
and not in order to make money
but in order to invent.
Terravision was an art project.
It was not about creating a product that you could sell on the Internet.
translation.ko: 인터넷에서 팔 수 있는 제품을 만든 게 아니라 "올리퍼 치겐발그 '빌리언 달러 코드' 제작자"

translation.en: It was about creating a piece of art.
translation.ko: "올리퍼 치겐발그 '빌리언 달러 코드' 제작자" 예술 작품을 만든 거였죠

translation.en: I mean, this is why I am in the arts.
It's because I'm interested in the potential of the arts
to really kind of inspire...
change.
Not necessarily the big change but, you know, little changes,
a little change of perspective.
Innovation needs space to dream.
And maybe more important, space to make mistakes.
Detours and complications create a deeper knowledge and understanding of your topic.
translation.ko: 우회와 복잡한 문제들은 주제에 대한 더 깊은 지식과 이해를 가져옵니다

translation.en: If you only repeat what was successful before,
you will probably never create something truly unique.
translation.ko: 어쩌면 정말 특별한 걸 만들 수 없을 겁니다
